qas.question: If Broca were alive today, what would his profession be?
What did Broca discover in the human brain?
What did the German philosopher Waitz specialize in?
How many volumes was Waitz work?
What did Broca leave neurosurgery to study?
Where did Broca think the similarity between man and other animals resided?
Who wrote a six-volume work on Biological anthropology?
What did Waitz write in the 18th century?

context: Broca, being what today would be called a <a0_0>neurosurgeon<a0_0/>, had taken an interest in <a1_0><b5_0>the pathology of speech<b5_0/><a1_0/>. He wanted to localize the difference between man and the other animals, which appeared to reside <b6_0>in speech<b6_0/>. He discovered the <a2_0>speech center<a2_0/> of the human brain, today called Broca's area after him. His interest was mainly in Biological anthropology, but a German philosopher specializing in <a3_0>psychology<a3_0/>, <b7_0>Theodor Waitz<b7_0/>, took up the theme of general and social anthropology in his <a4_0>six<a4_0/>-volume work, entitled <b8_0>Die Anthropologie der Naturvölker<b8_0/>, 1859–1864. The title was soon translated as "The Anthropology of Primitive Peoples". The last two volumes were published posthumously.
